H.S. and H.A. conceived the project and wrote the paper, with input from other authors. H.S. performed all 2p experiments, including 2p imaging, 2p mesoscope imaging, 2p holographic optogenetics and 2p holographic mesoscope experiments. M.B.O. assisted with the design and execution of 2p holographic optogenetic experiments. L.A. designed and built the 2p holographic remote-focusing microscope, with assistance from M.B.O.; and invented and built the 2p holographic mesoscope, with assistance from H.S. and U.K.J. L.A. and U.K.J. assisted with 2p holographic mesoscope experiments. S.D. managed recordings. B.H. assisted with recordings and technical support. H.B., H.C. and H.L. performed Neuropixels recordings. A.B., B.H. and J.L. preprocessed the Neuropixels data and packaged it in the NeuroData Without Borders format. J.W., K.N., L.S., T.J., W.H., B.O. and C.G. performed surgery for Neuropixels experiments. J.S. performed behavioral habituation for Neuropixels experiments. V.H., A.Y. and S.C. performed Intrinsic signal imaging for Neuropixels experiments. S.D., S.C., A.W., P.A.G., S.O., C.K. and J.L. managed various aspects of the Neuropixels experiments. J.L. managed all aspects of the OpenScope collaboration.

a, Schematic of visual stimulus sequences during the experiment. Throughout each IC visual block, the four circles were present in all stimulus frames. b, Images in the IC block were presented in four distinct types of blocks. The default block, ICwcfg1, has four white circles in each quadrant on black background. In the ICwcfg0 block, images are rotated 315° clockwise relative to ICwcfg1. ICkcfg1 and ICkcfg0 are black–white inverted from ICwcfg1 and ICwcfg0, respectively. c, Images shown in a ICwcfg1 block.

a, Top, pupil position on an example session. Bottom, contours demarcate, for each session, the isolines for the value of 0.01 in the two-dimensional probability distribution function (PDF). IC1 vs. LC1 vs. LC2 vs. IC2 images are shown in the background for relative scale. Mouse eye gaze is confined to a small region that fits within the illusory gap region. There are no systematic differences in pupil position among IC1 vs. LC1 vs. LC2 vs. IC2 presentations. b, Fixed-gaze trials were defined as trials where the pupil position stayed within 8 visual degrees of the mode pupil position throughout the duration of the trial. When analyzing only fixed-gaze trials, there were n = 11 exclusively center-responsive V1 RS units; 10 sessions had eye tracking data and of these, 9 sessions had a valid receptive field mapping block where the fixed-gaze constraint left at least one trial in each position. c, PSTH of exclusively center-responsive V1 RS units on IC and IRE trials, for preferred IRE orientation and corresponding IC and segment image trials (mean ± s.e.m. across n = 11 neurons). These neurons respond to IRE images and less strongly to IC images, but not to the individual segments on either side of the illusory contour. d, PSTH on IC and IRE trials for preferred IRE orientation and corresponding IC trials (top: mean ± s.e.m. across neurons, bottom: individual neurons with significantly IC-responsive (left) and IRE-responsive (right) neurons marked in magenta on the y axis). e, Top, comparison of the preferred orientation between ICs (IC stimuli) and real edges (IRE stimuli) for exclusively center-responsive V1 RS units. Bottom, CDF for the null distribution, acquired by shuffling the preferred IC vs. IRE orientations among exclusively center-responsive V1 RS units. Actual match proportion is indicated with a red dotted line. f, Match between receptive field position mapped with fixed-gaze trials vs. all trials. Match proportion is 0.81 among 398 V1 RS units with significant receptive fields (p < 0.05 Kruskal–Wallis test across responses to 9 positions in the receptive field mapping block). g, Pupil area, z-scored across each recording session, during visual presentation of various images in the IC block (n = 10 sessions with eye tracking data; p = 0.7220 Friedman test). Box-and-whisker plots are formatted as follows: centerline, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; whiskers, 1.5× interquartile range; circles, outliers.

a, 2p imaging sessions with IC block images that had larger gaps between white circles; the gap size between diagonal white circles was 24 visual degree gaps (4 sessions from 2 mice). b, Receptive fields were mapped with 16 visual degree circular patches in 9 positions, spaced 16 visual degrees apart, same as Extended Data Fig. 5. There were n = 32 exclusively center-responsive V1 layer 2/3 excitatory neurons. c, PSTH on IC and IRE trials for preferred IRE orientation and corresponding IC trials (top: mean ± s.e.m. across neurons, bottom: individual neurons individual neurons with significantly IC-responsive (left) and IRE-responsive (right) neurons marked in magenta on the y axis). d, Top, comparison of the preferred orientation between ICs (IC stimuli) and real edges (IRE stimuli) for exclusively center-responsive V1 layer 2/3 excitatory neurons. Bottom, CDF for match proportions in shuffled distributions is shown as a black solid curve, actual match proportion in red dotted line. e, 2p imaging sessions with dense receptive field mapping and standard IC block images (30 visual degree white circles and 16 visual degree gaps; 5 sessions from 2 mice). f, Receptive fields were mapped with 16 visual degree circular patches in 17 positions, spaced 8 visual degrees apart (dense mapping, as in Extended Data Fig. 2). Of note, evoked response heatmaps are not drawn to proportion (heatmap circles have half the diameter of the actual circular patches used for mapping). Receptive field positions were determined for neurons with p < 0.05 Kruskal–Wallis test for responses across circular patch positions. There were n = 71 V1 layer 2/3 excitatory neurons with receptive fields in the center position. g,h, Same as c and d, but for V1 layer 2/3 excitatory neurons with receptive fields in the center position in dense mapping sessions. i, 2p imaging sessions with IC blocks that had gray background (50% contrast), with 30 visual degree white circles and 16 visual degree gaps (7 sessions from 3 mice). Top, these blocks contained contrast real edge images (CRE) in addition to outline real edge images (IRE). Bottom, PSTHs of exclusively center-responsive neurons show similar evoked responses to CRE and IRE, and smaller evoked responses to IC (mean ± s.e.m. across n = 38 exclusively center-responsive V1 layer 2/3 excitatory neurons). j, Receptive fields were mapped with 16 visual degree circular patches in 9 positions, spaced 16 visual degrees apart, same as b. k,l, Same as c and d, but for CRE trials instead of IRE trials in 50% contrast sessions. m,n, Same as c and d, but for 50% contrast sessions.

a, Receptive fields (RF) of all neurons were mapped using 16-degree patches of circular drifting gratings appearing in one of the nine positions depicted (top). Position 1 corresponds to the gap region in IC and LC images (bottom; for reference, the nine positions in the receptive field mapping block are shown on top of the default image from the IC block). Note, 16 degrees is slightly larger than the typical size of receptive fields in mouse V1. b, Example IC1-encoder (top) and IC2-encoder (bottom), showing its receptive field (left), PSTHs to IC and LC images (center), and PSTHs to inward segment images (right). PSTHs are calculated in 1 ms bins and smoothed with a Gaussian kernel that has an s.d. of 5 ms and is 25-ms long. c, Receptive fields percentage in each position for IC-encoders (left, two panels) and segment responders (right, four panels). IC-encoders' receptive fields are not biased toward the illusory gap region (n = 367/386 IC1/IC2-encoders in 24 sessions from 4 mice). On the contrary, segment responders' receptive fields are biased toward the image segments that are used to define them (n = 552/482/409/410 BR/BL/TL/TR segment responders in 24 sessions from 4 mice). d, Positions of circular patches used for dense receptive field mapping shown in cyan and yellow lines, relative to the IC block ‘blank' image (19 sessions from 5 mice). e, IC-encoders' receptive fields percentage in each position (n = 458/578 IC1/IC2-encoders). First and third panels show circular patches and their relative positions in actual proportions; second and fourth panels show the same data with smaller circular patches for clarity. f, IC block images were scaled up by 1.5× (10 sessions from 5 mice). Receptive fields were mapped with 16 visual degree square patches positioned in a 5 × 5 grid. g, IC-encoders' receptive fields percentage in each position (n = 129/126 IC1/IC2-encoders). Second and fourth panels show the receptive field distribution in red, and 95% bootstrapped confidence intervals of IC-responsive/LC-responsive neurons in black. h–i, Decoder performance for images scaled up by 1.5× (n = 10 sessions from 5 mice). *p < 0.05 Wilcoxon signed-rank test compared to chance of 0.25 for cross-validation accuracy in h (p = 0.0020) and 0 for TRE inference score in i (p = 0.0020). Box-and-whisker plots are formatted as follows: centerline, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; whiskers, 1.5x interquartile range; circles, outliers.

a, Illusory bars are perceived as dark bars on white-circles blocks (n = 11 sessions from 5 mice) and light bars on black-circles blocks (n = 9 sessions from 6 mice). b, IC-encoders' orientation tuning was measured using single lines that span the entire screen; dark bars were used for IC-encoders identified in white-circles blocks and light bars for black-circles blocks. For both white-circles blocks and black-circles blocks, IC-encoders are tuned to the orientation of the illusory bar that they are selective for (mean ± s.e.m. across neurons; white-circles block n = 93 IC1-encoders and n = 159 IC2-encoders, black-circles block n = 409 IC1-encoders and n = 482 IC2-encoders; Wilcoxon signed-rank test for orientation of the illusory bar vs. orthogonal orientation p = 0.0017 in the white-circles block, p = 2.6 × 10−8 in the black-circles block). c, Size tuning was measured using circular patches of drifting gratings in various sizes, positioned at the center of the monitor. Size tuning for neurons with receptive fields in the center position is shown in black (mean ± s.e.m. across n = 1638 neurons with p < 0.05 Kruskal–Wallis test across responses to 9 positions, maximal activity in the center); size tuning for IC-encoders with receptive fields in the center is shown in green (n = 12 center-receptive field IC-encoders in the white-circles block, n = 48 in the black-circles block). Receptive field size measured in this way is not distinct for IC-encoders compared to other visually responsive neurons. d, Circular patches of drifting gratings with 16 visual degree diameters were shown in 17 different positions spaced 8 visual degrees apart, as shown in Extended Data Fig. 2d. Number of patches that IC-encoders respond to is not different from IC-responsive neurons (error bars indicate 95% bootstrapped confidence interval). e, When decoding across all neurons recorded in each V1 layer 2/3 imaging session, TRE-evoked neural activity patterns are more likely to be decoded as IC than LC on both white-circles blocks (Wilcoxon signed-rank test p = 0.0020 across n = 11 sessions) and black-circles blocks (Wilcoxon signed-rank test p = 0.0273 across n = 9 sessions). Error bars indicate mean ± s.e.m. across sessions, and gray lines indicate paired TRE inference decoding performance for each session.

a, IC/LC images used to define IC-encoders and segment responders in this figure. b, For the Neuropixels dataset, proportion of V1 IC-encoders (left, n = 87) and V1 segment responders (right, n = 636) in each layer. In c–f, same dataset as Fig. 3d,e (left: of 12 sessions in Neuropixels dataset, sessions with <50 RS units are excluded, which leaves n = 12, 8, 11, 10, 12 and 11 sessions for V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively; right: n = 8/11/19 sessions for V1L4 FOV, V1L2/3 FOV, and mesoscope FOV, respectively. For each visual area, sessions with <100 neurons in that area are excluded, which leaves n = 8, 11, 19, 8, 15, 2, 6 and 1 sessions for V1L4, V1L2/3, mesoscope V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively). In c,d, box-and-whisker plots are formatted as follows: centerline, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; whiskers, 1.5x interquartile range; circles, outliers. c, Proportion of IC-encoders, out of all neurons, in each area. d, Proportion of IC-encoders, out of visually responsive neurons, in each area. Visually responsive neurons are defined as neurons that respond to at least one of IC/LC images (p < 0.05 Kruskal–Wallis test across responses to blank vs. IC1 vs. LC1 vs. LC2 vs. IC2). In e,f, response on IC vs. LC trials, averaged across all neurons (e) or visually responsive neurons (f) for each session (mean ± s.e.m. across sessions, paired data for each session indicated with gray lines). IC images do not evoke greater responses than LC images (*p < 0.05 one-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test for testing IC > LC; note that none of the visual areas showed significance). e, Response on IC vs. LC trials, averaged across all neurons. In Neuropixels dataset, one-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test for testing IC > LC returned p = 0.9614, 0.9805, 0.7676, 0.7217, 0.9895 and 0.8398 for V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively. In 2p dataset, p = 0.7266, 0.9932, 0.8476, 0.8086, 0.9794, 0.5000, 0.2188 and 1.0000 for V1L4, V1L2/3, mesoscope V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively. f, Response on IC vs. LC trials, averaged across visually responsive neurons. In Neuropixels dataset, one-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test for testing IC > LC returned p = 0.9788, 0.9805, 0.7114, 0.7842, 0.9866 and 0.6499 for V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively. In 2p dataset, p = 0.8750, 0.9878, 0.8902, 0.9023, 0.9990, 0.2500, 0.3438 and 1.0000 for V1L4, V1L2/3, mesoscope V1, LM, RL, AL, PMz and AM, respectively.

In a–c, box-and-whisker plots are formatted as follows: centerline, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; whiskers, 1.5x interquartile range; circles, outliers. a, Same data as Fig. 2, but showing statistical comparisons between areas (12 sessions from 12 mice; for each area in the Neuropixels dataset, sessions with <50 RS units are excluded, which leaves n = 12, 8, 11, 10, 12 and 11 sessions for V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively; Kruskal–Wallis test p = 0.0019 for cross-validation accuracy across areas, p = 0.0249 for TRE inference score). b, XRE inference decoding entails probing IC-evoked neural activity patterns with decoders trained to discriminate between XRE-evoked neural activity patterns. XRE inference score was defined as (P(IC1 → XRE1) + P(IC2 → XRE2))/2. As with TRE inference decoding (Fig. 2), layer 2/3 of V1 and LM consistently show high inference scores (*p < 0.05, Wilcoxon signed-rank test compared to chance of 0.5; left: of 12 sessions in Neuropixels dataset, sessions with <50 RS units are excluded, which leaves n = 12, 8, 11, 10, 12 and 11 sessions with p = 0.0005, 0.0078, 0.0049, 0.0020, 0.0005 and 0.0137 for V1, LM, RL, AL, PM and AM, respectively; right: n = 8/11/19 sessions for V1L4 FOV, V1L2/3 FOV, and mesoscope FOV, respectively. For each visual area, sessions with <100 neurons in that area are excluded, which leaves n = 8, 11, 19, 8, 15, 2, 6 and 1 sessions with p = 0.4609, 0.0020, 0.0007, 0.0078, 0.0054, 0.5000, 0.4375 and 1.0000 for V1L4, V1L2/3, mesoscope V1, LM, RL, AL, PM, and AM, respectively). c, Same data as b, but showing statistical comparisons between areas (Kruskal–Wallis test p = 0.0005 for cross-validation accuracy across areas, p = 0.0022 for XRE inference score).

a, Lateral (left) and axial (right) physiological point spread functions (PPSF) of the two-photon holographic photo-stimulation system, measured in GCaMP6m–ChRmine expressing neurons (mean ± s.e.m. across n = 294 neurons). b, Holography evoked responses in nonphotoactivated neurons (>50 μm from all targets in each ensemble), for neurons that are visually responsive to the corresponding IC image (x axis) vs. nonresponsive neurons (y axis) (24 sessions from 4 mice). Holography-evoked response was measured during the photoactivation window (0–1 s relative to holography onset), and baseline activity was subtracted (−1 to 0 s relative to holography onset). Left, targeting IC-encoders evoked significantly larger activity in IC-responsive neurons than nonresponsive neurons (p = 0.0023 one-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test across n = 32 holographic ensembles). Right, targeting segment responders did not evoke a larger activity in IC-responsive neurons compared to nonresponsive neurons (p = 0.9660 across n = 37 holographic ensembles). c, PSTH of holography evoked responses. Baseline activity was subtracted as in b. Top, holography-driven PSTH averaged across all neurons in each group (mean ± s.e.m. across neurons; IC-responsive in red, nonresponsive in black). Bottom, holography-driven PSTH shown as a heatmap for each neuron in each group. d, Same as top panels in c (mean ± s.e.m. across neurons), but also showing targeted neurons in each holographic ensemble (cyan). Activity in directly photoactivated neurons is an order of magnitude higher than the activity in nonphotoactivated neurons. e, PSTH of visual evoked responses, for the same group of neurons shown in d (mean ± s.e.m. across neurons; directedly targeted neurons in cyan, nonphotoactivated IC-responsive neurons in red, nonphotoactivated non-IC-responsive neurons in black).

In a–d, decoders were constructed with nonphotoactivated neurons, separately for each holographic ensemble (>50 μm from all targets in each ensemble; 24 sessions from 4 mice expressing GCaMP6m–ChRmine in V1 neurons). a, Holography-evoked response patterns are classified into the image that evoked the most similar visual response patterns. The expected classification given the holographic ensemble is marked with ‘o'. Only the holographic ensembles with ≥10 targets were analyzed (n = 17 IC1-encoder ensembles, n = 15 IC2-encoder ensembles). b, The proportion of holography trials decoded as the expected visual label (y axis), as a function of the number of targets in each holographic ensemble (left); tenfold cross-validation accuracy of the decoder trained on visual responses (middle); and the proportion of holography trials decoded as the expected visual label when decoder was trained on all neurons (right) (ρ denotes the Spearman correlation across holographic ensembles; n = 24 IC1-encoder ensembles, n = 24 IC2-encoder ensembles). c, Same as a, but for segment responder ensembles (n = 19 BR + TL segment responder ensembles, n = 18 BL + TR segment responder ensembles). d, Same as b, but for segment responder ensembles (n = 24 BR + TL segment responder ensembles, n = 24 BL + TR segment responder ensembles). e–h, Decoders were trained on neurons that were commonly nonphotoactivated across four holographic ensembles; IC1-encoders, IC2-encoders, BR + TL segment responders and BL + TR segment responders (>50 μm from all targets across these four ensembles). Otherwise, same as a–d.

a, LC-encoders are defined as neurons that respond to either LC1 or LC2, but not to either IC1 or IC2 (p < 0.05 Kruskal–Wallis test across responses to blank vs. IC1 vs. LC1 vs. LC2 vs. IC2, post hoc Tukey–Kramer test). In b–g, LC-encoders were targeted in two distinct holographic ensembles; LC1-encoder photoactivation is expected to be decoded as LC1, and LC2-encoder photoactivation is expected to be decoded as LC2 (n = 24 sessions from 4 mice expressing GCaMP6m–ChRmine in V1 neurons). b, Visual responses of neurons in each holographic ensemble. Mean ± s.e.m. across n = 428 LC1-encoders, n = 292 LC2-encoders, n = 354 IC1-encoders, n = 372 IC2-encoders, n = 424 BR + TL segment responders, n = 409 BL + TR segment responders. In c–e, only the holographic ensembles with ≥10 targets were analyzed (n = 35, 32 and 37 ensembles for LC-encoders, IC-encoders and segment responders, respectively). Box-and-whisker plots are formatted as follows: centerline, median; box limits, upper and lower quartiles; whiskers, 1.5x interquartile range; circles, outliers. c, To compare visual information contained in holographic ensembles, we compared the tenfold cross-validation accuracy of visual responses for targeted neurons on corresponding visual trials; LC-encoder ensembles on LC trials (LC1/LC2-encoders on LC1/LC2 trials, respectively), IC-encoder ensembles on IC trials (IC1/IC2-encoders on IC1/IC2 trials, respectively) and segment responder ensembles on IC trials (BR + TL/BL + TR segment responders on IC1/IC2 trials, respectively; Kruskal–Wallis test p = 2.0 × 10−8, followed by Bonferroni–Holm corrected Wilcoxon rank-sum tests *p < 0.05). d, Decoders constructed with all neurons were trained on visual evoked activity patterns and used to classify holography evoked activity patterns. Only the holographic ensembles with ≥10 targets were analyzed (n = 35, 32 and 37 ensembles for LC-encoders, IC-encoders and segment responders, respectively; Kruskal-Wallis test p = 2.4 × 10−11, followed by Bonferroni–Holm corrected Wilcoxon rank-sum tests *p < 0.05). e, Decoders were constructed with nonphotoactivated neurons for each holographic ensemble (Kruskal–Wallis test p = 0.0012, followed by Bonferroni–Holm corrected Wilcoxon rank-sum tests *p < 0.05). f, Relationship between visual information contained in each holographic ensemble (x axis; shown in c), and the decoding of holographically driven activity in nonphotoactivated neurons (y axis; shown in e). Cross-validation accuracy of holographic ensembles (x axis) was divided into 6 equidistant bins between 0 and 1, and mean ± s.e.m. decoder performance (y axis) of each bin was plotted for three groups of holographic ensembles (orange: n = 35 LC-encoder ensembles, green: n = 32 IC-encoder ensembles, magenta: n = 37 segment responder ensembles). g, For the three groups of holographic ensembles, cross-validation accuracies of targets were matched by matching the number of samples in each x-axis bin shown in f. Specifically, in each of the three bins where all three groups had data, we chose the group with the highest number of samples, and bootstrapped data in the other two groups to match the sample number. As a result, the bootstrapped distributions were matched in cross-validation accuracies of targets (left; n = 48 ensembles in each group, Kruskal–Wallis test p = 0.5811). When comparing the decoding performance of holographically driven activity in nonphotoactivated neurons among these bootstrapped distributions, we again see the highest performance when targeting IC-encoders (right; n = 48 ensembles in each group, Kruskal–Wallis test p = 0.0022, followed by Bonferroni–Holm corrected Wilcoxon rank-sum tests *p < 0.05). Box-and-whisker plots are formatted as in c–e.

Title: The rising danger of AI-generated images in nanomaterials science and what we can do about it
Description:

Nature Nanotechnology

                         (2025)Cite this article


Generative AI has made it trivial to generate fake microscopy images that are indistinguishable from real images, even for experts. As researchers in nanoscience, it is time for us to face this reality and discuss strategies to conserve the integrity of our discipline.

Title: GPS timekeeping is increasingly vulnerable: here's how to deliver future-proofed time
Description:

            and JavaScript.

Advertisement

Leon Lobo is the head of the National Timing Centre research and development programme at the National Physical Laboratory, Teddington, UK.


Search author on:
PubMed
 Google Scholar


Douglas Paul holds the Royal Academy of Engineering Chair in emerging technologies at the James Watt School of Engineering, University of Glasgow, Glasgow, UK.


Search author on:
PubMed

Search author on:
PubMed

Aviation and road transport are among the sectors that currently depend on increasingly vulnerable GPS timekeeping. Credit: Kevin Carter/Getty

It might not be apparent, but almost everything people do in this digitally connected world, from sending a text or e-mail to doing an Internet search or paying for something online, depends on accurate, resilient timing. Most electronic communications rely on digital infrastructure that is synchronized to a common time reference, enabling information to flow at a known rate. Accurate timing is also crucial for synchronizing and stabilizing infrastructure such as electricity grids, for helping to ensure the integrity of financial transactions, for steering machinery for precision agriculture, and for managing transport, logistics and postal delivery systems, among a host of other essential functions.

Today, the necessary timing signals come overwhelmingly from Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS). These deliver signals from space, with only a radio receiver needed to receive and interpret them. Chief among them is the US-developed Global Positioning System (GPS). GPS is free to use, and the technology is mature: miniature GPS receivers are now embedded in every smartphone, at a cost of a few dollars per unit. This is an easy, low-cost way to reliably synchronize time, certainly compared with the old method of physically calibrating your clock to a reference clock at a national standards agency.

Best ever clocks: breakthrough paves way for ultra-precise ‘nuclear' timekeepers

Best ever clocks: breakthrough paves way for ultra-precise ‘nuclear' timekeepers

But this success has bred complacency — and led to underappreciated risk. GNSS are far from fail-safe. In many parts of the world, organized-crime syndicates and military authorities are among those increasingly jamming GNSS signals (blocking them entirely) or spoofing them (transmitting false signals to provide misleading time and position coordinates). Disruptions to the signal due to extreme weather events are also on the rise. In some sectors, such as aviation, a multitude of systems would potentially be affected in the event of more-widespread outages. But there is low awareness of the risks — and protections are hugely variable between sectors.

The increasing vulnerability of time signals from space necessitates the development of alternative ways of accessing accurate, resilient and secure time. We (the authors) have been involved in varying capacities in technology and economic measures to deliver a nationwide, resilient terrestrial timing solution that is independent of GNSS in the United Kingdom. Here we set out three key steps that we think would help to facilitate the development of alternative time sources worldwide: increasing buy-in from business; linking up existing, heterogeneous local timing systems; and creating entirely new uses for time.

Constellations of GNSS satellites disseminate time from the national-standards laboratories that contribute to the formulation of the global time scale, Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). The GPS system was developed by the US Department of Defense during the cold war, initially for the exclusive use of the US military. Each GPS satellite carries multiple atomic clocks, which are ultimately synchronized with a representation of the UTC, known as UTC(USNO), generated by an ensemble of atomic clocks at the US Naval Observatory in Washington DC. The signals these satellites beam down to Earth enable users to determine the time to within an accuracy of 10–7 seconds, or 100 billionths of a second.

Recognition in the 1980s of the wider potential societal benefits of GNSS led the United States to make an intentionally degraded, ‘selectively available' version of the GPS signal accessible to everyone globally, free of charge. The full version was made public in 2000, since when its use has ballooned in a plethora of civilian applications. Other GNSS systems exist, such as GLONASS (operated by Russia), Galileo (the European Union) and BeiDou (China). But GPS remains dominant owing to widespread public confidence in a US-provided infrastructure and to the system's earlier availability for general use, which means a large number of older receivers are only GPS-compliant. Some 5.6 billion end-user GNSS receiver units were in use in 2023, a number predicted to increase to almost 9 billion units in 2033 (see ‘Sky-high demand'). The economic benefits of using GNSS have been estimated to be around US$300 billion annually for the United States, $81 billion across Europe and from $9 billion to about $18 billion for the United Kingdom (see ‘Productivity plus').

Source: EU Agency for the Space Programme (https://go.nature.com/42AQKJL)

The potential costs of disruption to GNSS are similarly considerable: across all sectors, a report for the UK government in 2023 estimated these costs, per day, to be almost $1.9 billion for the United Kingdom alone. But whereas the economic benefits of using GNSS often accrue to individual firms, the economic cost of disturbances to the GPS signal — for example, the failure of the electricity grid due to a GPS outage that might affect transport, financial and communication systems — tends to be borne by all of society.

More onus needs to be put on firms and utilities that provide services through GNSS to invest in timing resilience. Regulation to increase the liability of individual firms, and personal accountability of senior managers for ensuring resilience of time, is one way to make this happen. There is also a need to support the development of alternative assured ‘holdover time' capabilities: accurate, locally based clocks that can continue to provide time for a while if the main GNSS signals are lost.

Source: London Economics (https://go.nature.com/4G5NDYM)

The cumulative investment costs across every organization in every sector to provide such a holdover system are likely to be significant. Developing national public infrastructures for delivering resilient timekeeping directly from national representations of UTC — in effect, recreating timekeeping as a national public utility — is a way to reduce direct costs for businesses. Such a public utility could instil trust and confidence in users, and cover its costs by offering tiered, paid-for levels of assurance of time. In the United Kingdom, a supporting terrestrial clock system is being designed and developed as a nationwide time infrastructure through the National Timing Centre research and development programme (of which one of us, L.L., is head) at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL) at Teddington. This system is linked to UTC(NPL), the United Kingdom's real-time realization of UTC.

But limited understanding of the need for alternative assured-time capabilities is a barrier to achieving business and political buy-in. A programme of public awareness about the use and importance of GNSS should be rolled out globally, emphasizing both the risks inherent in the current systems and the benefits of alternative timing systems for increased resilience and enhanced performance.

Crucial infrastructures, from financial services to transport and energy systems, are often interdependent. Yet they tend to operate as independent ecosystems, subject to their own legislation and with their own regulatory standards, policies, supply chains and digital ecosystems.

Little thought tends to be given to the security of timekeeping in the design and maintenance of the digital systems underpinning this infrastructure. Time's intangible nature means that it often falls in the gap between cybersecurity and physical-security measures designed to protect digital and physical assets, respectively. When mitigating GNSS loss or disruption is considered at all, it tends to be by individual firms on an ad hoc basis. For example, telecommunications network providers often have atomic clocks distributed across their fibre exchanges to enable synchronization to be maintained for the Internet backbone even if GNSS signals are disrupted. Such mitigation measures are rarely tested robustly for the possibility of GNSS outages across all interconnected sectors.

Atomic clock keeps ultra-precise time aboard a rocking naval ship

Atomic clock keeps ultra-precise time aboard a rocking naval ship

The increasingly interlinked nature of timing infrastructure implies that terrestrial clocks need to be integrated and able to coordinate time in the case of disruption to GNSS. This underlines the desirability of government intervention to provide a base capability that is accessible to all users wherever and whenever they need it. This might take the form of new legislation or regulation and standards to allow interoperability between essential infrastructures. It is part of the rationale behind the UK National Timing Centre's research programme.

A further consideration is that the global supply chain for timing systems — from atomic clocks, time distribution and monitoring systems to user equipment — is currently sparse and lacks diversity. The ubiquity and utility of GNSS for time has resulted in industry investing in and developing receivers that are low in size, weight, power and cost, proliferating dependency on this single solution. (One of us, D.P., is head of the UK Hub for Quantum Enabled Position, Navigation and Timing, led by the University of Glasgow, UK, which runs a programme developing cheaper timing technologies.) A more diverse supply chain needs to be built to provide the enabling technologies to support a national timing infrastructure that can enhance the resilience of time. This needs to be complemented by an upgrade of the skills pipeline.

Private-sector investments in building such a resilient supply chain to provide reliable timing will depend on effective, long-term commitment from governments1. Policy initiatives such as direct public investment, or incentives such as tax credits, interest deferrals and loans, must be immune to political winds of change to truly de-risk such investments. This could be achieved by regulating the minimum holdover time — the length of time any backup system can provide accurate timekeeping — across industries to ensure commitment to build and develop such time-based resilience. Such regulation needs to define the requirements for specific clocks with the accuracy needed to enable each national infrastructure to operate effectively.

The extra revenue-generating opportunity of new timing systems is, on the face of it, limited when compared with the extra costs. A focus solely on managing risk and enhancing the resilience of time systems might not, therefore, be enough to convince firms of the need to invest in supporting the development of terrestrial holdover timing systems.

Financial markets require precise, trustable time for transactions to be recorded accurately.Caption: Michael M. Santiago/Getty

Title: Scaling up spatial transcriptomics for large-sized tissues: uncovering cellular-level tissue architecture beyond conventional platforms with iSCALE
