Nature Methods

                         (2025)Cite this article


Recent advances in spatial transcriptomics (ST) technologies have transformed our ability to profile gene expression while preserving crucial spatial context within tissues. However, existing ST platforms are constrained by high costs, long turnaround times, low resolution, limited gene coverage and inherently small tissue capture areas, which hinder their broad applications. Here we present iSCALE, a method that reconstructs large-scale, super-resolution gene expression landscapes and automatically annotates cellular-level tissue architecture in samples exceeding capture areas of current ST platforms. The performance of iSCALE was assessed by comprehensive evaluations involving benchmarking experiments, immunohistochemistry staining and manual annotations by pathologists. When applied to multiple sclerosis human brain samples, iSCALE uncovered lesion-associated cellular characteristics undetectable by conventional ST experiments. Our results demonstrate the utility of iSCALE in analyzing large tissues by enabling unbiased annotation, resolving cell type composition, mapping cellular microenvironments and revealing spatial features beyond the reach of standard ST analysis or routine histopathological assessment.

Understanding spatial gene expression distributions across tissues is essential for answering crucial biological questions and uncovering cellular functions, disease mechanisms and tissue development. ST technologies have transformed our ability to profile gene expression across tissues while retaining crucial spatial context1,2,3. However, major barriers to the widespread adoption of commercial ST platforms in biomedical research include high costs, long turnaround times, low resolution, limited gene coverage and inherently small tissue capture areas offered by current ST platforms. Sequencing-based ST platforms, such as Visium4, can sequence the whole transcriptome but lack single-cell resolution and come with a limited standard tissue capture area of 6.5 mm × 6.5 mm. Although Visium offers an extended version with a larger capture area of 11 mm × 11 mm, it is more expensive than the standard version. Additionally, many tissue samples still surpass this size limitation, restricting spatial profiling to a small portion of a biopsy or organ and often missing key biological regions. The recently released Visium HD5 offers subcellular resolution but at considerably higher cost than Visium, and its tissue capture area is only 6.5 mm × 6.5 mm. Imaging-based ST platforms such as MERSCOPE6, CosMx7 and Xenium8 provide subcellular resolution and can handle moderately larger tissues, but the number of genes is limited, and image scanning time is typically extensive. These limitations make commercial ST platforms impractical for large-scale investigations, particularly when studying sizable tissues common in human studies. A recent approach, ‘visiumStitched'9, attempts to extend the spatial profiling window by manually stitching a few Visium captures; however, it requires manual alignment and supports only low-resolution analysis of directly measured regions.

On the other hand, hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained histology images, routinely used by clinical pathology laboratories, are considerably more cost-effective than ST. Additionally, the physical size of a standard whole-slide H&E image can be as large as 25 mm × 75 mm, greatly exceeding the capture area of all ST platforms. Previous studies showed correlations between gene expression profiles and histological image characteristics10,11,12,13,14,15, suggesting the feasibility of inferring spatial gene expression from these histology images16,17,18,19,20. Because obtaining histology images from large-sized tissues is easily achievable, this opens the possibility of virtually predicting gene expression directly from histology, overcoming the tissue size limitations of conventional ST platforms.

Here we introduce iSCALE (inferring Spatially resolved Cellular Architectures in Large-sized tissue Environments), a novel machine learning framework designed to predict gene expression for large-sized tissues with cellular-level resolution. By leveraging the gene expression–histological feature relationship, learned from a small set of training ST captures, iSCALE enables comprehensive gene expression prediction and tissue annotation across entire large tissue sections, including regions without direct gene expression measurements. Unlike existing resolution enhancement methods such as iStar16 and RedeHist19, which rely on a single ST capture for prediction, iSCALE aligns and combines information from distinct ST sections and leverages large-sized H&E images to infer gene expression across extensive tissue areas. This is achieved by mapping individual sections onto the full tissue image and integrating information across multiple ST captures to enable spatially continuous gene expression prediction. This flexible framework allows iSCALE to provide a more comprehensive and scalable approach for spatial gene expression analysis compared to current state-of-the-art methods. Our results demonstrate that iSCALE can provide critical insights into disease by generating high-resolution spatial gene expression maps for large tissue sections.

An overview of the iSCALE workflow is shown in Fig. 1. Our goal is to predict gene expression in an H&E image generated from a large-sized tissue section, referred to as the ‘mother image'. The pipeline begins by selecting regions from the same tissue block, potentially spanning adjacent sections, with regions fitting standard ST platform capture areas (Extended Data Fig. 1). This process generates a small set of training ST captures, referred to as ‘daughter captures'. iSCALE then implements spatial clustering analysis on the daughter ST data to guide the alignment of the daughter captures onto the mother image through a human-in-the-loop, semiautomatic process (Extended Data Fig. 2a–c). Next, iSCALE harmoniously integrates the gene expression and spatial information across the aligned daughter captures. To construct a gene expression prediction model, iSCALE extracts both global and local tissue structure information from the mother image. Subsequently, a feedforward neural network is employed to learn the relationship between histological image features and gene expression transferred from the aligned daughter captures. The resulting model predicts gene expression for each 8-µm × 8-µm superpixel—corresponding to approximately the size of a single cell—across the entire mother image. Leveraging these predictions, iSCALE further annotates each superpixel in the mother image with cell types and identifies enriched cell types in each tissue region, providing a detailed characterization of tissue architecture at cellular resolution.

iSCALE enables ST analysis in large-sized tissues using a multi-capture study design. A high-resolution mother H&E image is obtained from a large tissue slice while multiple standard-sized daughter ST captures containing both gene expression and spatial information are collected from adjacent slices. iSCALE aligns and integrates the daughter captures based on gene expression, corrects for batch effects and smooths across spatial neighborhoods. Histological features are hierarchically extracted from regions of the mother image and combined with integrated ST data to predict super-resolution gene expression across the entire large tissue section. These predictions are then used for automatic cell type annotation and tissue segmentation. iSCALE also supports out-of-sample predictions for additional tissue sections using only H&E images. px, pixel.

To evaluate the effectiveness of iSCALE, we conducted a benchmarking experiment using a ground truth single-cell gene expression dataset derived from a large gastric cancer tissue section profiled with 10x Xenium (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15164980)21. The section contains 377 genes and spans the full Xenium slide (12 mm × 24 mm), making it ideal for benchmarking. In this experiment, we simulated a scenario where gene expression data were available only from a set of daughter captures, each with size of 3.2 mm × 3.2 mm, mimicking the conditions typically observed in real large tissue studies. Within each daughter capture, we simulated pseudo-Visium data, following the spot size and layout of the Visium platform (Fig. 2a). First, to assess the accuracy of iSCALE's semiautomatic alignment algorithm, we aligned daughter captures using the proposed algorithm described in the Methods section and achieved 99% alignment accuracy (Extended Data Fig. 2d). Next, the iSCALE model was trained using the integrated gene expression data from five daughter captures, assuming their true alignment on the mother image. For comparison, we also predicted gene expression using iStar16 and RedeHist19. Because both iStar and RedeHist can process only one daughter capture at a time to build their prediction models, we applied these algorithms for each daughter capture. As RedeHist requires a reference single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) dataset, we used a gastric tumor scRNA-seq dataset from Cheng et al.22.

a, Overview of the benchmarking design. Ground truth single-cell gene expression data were obtained using 10x Xenium. Five daughter captures, each measuring 3.2 mm × 3.2 mm, were generated with pseudo-Visium gene expression data. Daughter captures were aligned and integrated to generate a training dataset for the iSCALE model. b, Pathologist manual annotation and tissue segmentation across entire tissue sample using the predicted super-resolution gene expressions from iSCALE, iStar and RedeHist. c, Detailed examination of the upper-left region of the tissue. For iStar and RedeHist, segmentation results from the D1-trained model are displayed, as D1 is the only daughter capture among the five that covers the boundary between the tumor and mucosa. d, TLSs annotated by pathologist and detected by iSCALE segmentation.

Figure 2b shows the tissue segmentation results obtained from iSCALE, iStar and RedeHist. iSCALE's segmentation closely resembles the pathologist's manual annotation and successfully identified key tissue structures, including tumor, tumor-infiltrated stroma, mucosa, submucosa, muscle and tertiary lymphoid structure (TLS). In contrast, iStar and RedeHist segmentations varied noticeably across the five models, depending on the daughter capture used for training. For instance, iStar struggled to distinguish between tumor and mucosa when using daughter captures D1 and D5 as the training data. RedeHist performed even more poorly, failing to identify tissue structures regardless of which daughter capture was used as the training data. This is likely due to its inability to correctly detect a large portion of the nuclei (Supplementary Fig. 1), a critical component of its algorithm. To further demonstrate the advantage of iSCALE, we focused on the upper-left region of the tissue containing signet ring cells (Fig. 2c), which are associated with aggressive gastric cancer and poor prognosis and play a critical role in guiding treatment23. iSCALE accurately identified the boundary between the poorly cohesive carcinoma region with signet ring cells and the adjacent gastric mucosa, with its inferred boundary closely aligning with the pathologist's manual annotation. However, both iStar and RedeHist failed to detect this boundary when using daughter capture D1, which covers that boundary for model training (Fig. 2c and Supplementary Fig. 2). As another demonstration, we examined the TLSs in this sample. Detecting TLSs in cancer is crucial because they are associated with improved immune responses, enhanced antitumor activity and better patient prognosis, making them key indicators of the tumor microenvironment's immune dynamics24,25,26. As shown in Fig. 2d, cluster 11 (peach color) identified by iSCALE closely aligns with the manually annotated TLSs. In contrast, iStar tends to detect false-positive TLSs, whereas RedeHist exhibited substantially lower detection accuracy (Supplementary Fig. 3). Notably, the daughter capture models that performed well in certain regions often performed poorly for other critical regions, demonstrating considerable variability among predictions. These results underscore the importance of integrating multiple daughter captures to accurately detect fine-grained tissue structures, such as TLSs.

The availability of the ground truth single-cell gene expression data in this benchmarking experiment enables a quantitative evaluation of iSCALE's gene expression prediction accuracy. Although iSCALE was designed for Visium (spot-level) ST data, its prediction model can be readily adapted to use Xenium (cellular-level) ST data for training. In the following evaluations, we compared two versions of iSCALE: iSCALE-Seq, which used pseudo-Visium data for training, and iSCALE-Img, which used Xenium data for training. To evaluate the prediction performance, we focused on the top 100 highly variable genes (HVGs). We computed the following metrics: root mean squared error (RMSE), structural similarity index measure (SSIM) and Pearson correlation. As shown in Fig. 3a,b, iSCALE-Seq outperformed iStar across all evaluation metrics, achieving performance similar to iSCALE-Img, despite being trained on spot-level resolution ST data. RedeHist was excluded from this comparison due to its unsatisfactory performance (Supplementary Fig. 4). Although the Pearson correlation coefficients for iSCALE-Img and iSCALE-Seq were generally low at the superpixel level (8 µm × 8 µm), the correlations improved as the superpixel size increased. Approximately 50% of the genes achieved correlation coefficients greater than 0.45 at a spatial resolution of 32 µm × 32 µm for iSCALE-Seq. Moreover, we observed that low correlation values at the superpixel level, such as r = 0.27 for ACTA2, still resulted in spatial distributions that almost perfectly resembled the ground truth predictions (Fig. 3c). Additionally, the top 100 spatially variable genes, identified by Moran's I, revealed even stronger performance by iSCALE (Extended Data Fig. 3a). Results across all genes in the dataset (Extended Data Fig. 3b) confirm iSCALE's robustness and consistent superior performance compared to iStar.

a,b, Quantitative comparison of iSCALE and iStar predictions using RMSE (lower is better), SSIM (higher is better) and Pearson correlation (higher is better) for the top 100 HVGs, evaluated separately for each iStar model (D1–D5), resulting in 500 gene-wise comparisons. Statistics were calculated across n = 1,971,625 superpixels. RMSE and SSIM were evaluated at 8-µm spatial resolution, whereas Pearson correlation was assessed at multiple spatial resolutions. iSCALE-Seq: iSCALE trained using pseudo-Visium data daughter captures. iSCALE-Img: iSCALE trained using Xenium data daughter captures. a, For each box plot, the boundaries of the box correspond to the interquartile range (IQR), spanning from the 25th percentile (lower quartile) to the 75th percentile (upper quartile), with the center line indicating the median (50th percentile). Whiskers extend to the minimum and maximum values within 1.5× IQR from the lower and upper quartiles, respectively. Data beyond the end of the whiskers are plotted individually. b, Direct comparison of iSCALE-Seq versus iStar predictions at the per-gene level; the blue diagonal line indicates parity between methods. c, Visualization of ground truth gene expression measured by Xenium and predicted super-resolution gene expression by iSCALE-Seq and iStar at the 8-µm spatial resolution. The red box highlights where TFF2 was expressed in the ground truth data.

Source data

For illustration purposes, we visualized gene expression predictions by iSCALE and iStar compared to the ground truth single-cell expression measured using Xenium (Fig. 3c and Extended Data Fig. 4). Across all examined genes, iSCALE's predictions showed the closest resemblance to the ground truth gene expression. For genes with distinct spatial patterns—for example, MYH11, TFF2, ACTA2 and CAPN8—iStar's predictions were highly dependent on the daughter capture used for training. Notably, the optimal capture varied by gene (Fig. 3c). This highlights the importance of integrating data from all daughter captures when constructing the prediction model, a strength clearly demonstrated by iSCALE.

Next, we evaluated iSCALE's performance for out-of-sample prediction, where the test sample was from a different subject and included only an H&E image with no available gene expression data. For this benchmarking experiment, we used two normal gastric tissue sections from different subjects (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15164978 and https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15164947)27,28, both profiled using the 10x Xenium platform with 377 genes. Each tissue section was relatively large, spanning the entire Xenium slide. For this scenario, we assumed that gene expression data were available from only 10 daughter captures (each 2 mm × 2 mm) in the training sample (Normal 1) (Fig. 4a), whereas the test sample (Normal 2) had no gene expression data. We also simulated eight daughter captures (each 2 mm × 2 mm) in Normal 2 (Fig. 4a) to compare iSCALE's out-of-sample and in-sample predictions. As shown in Fig. 4b, the segmentation result from the out-of-sample predictions closely aligns with that from the cellular-level in-sample prediction and pathologist annotation, achieving an adjusted Rand index of 0.74 when comparing the two segmentations.

a, Overview of the benchmarking design. Ground truth gene expression data were obtained using 10x Xenium. Ten daughter captures for Normal 1 (N1) and eight daughter captures for Normal 2 (N2), each measuring 2 mm × 2 mm, were generated with pseudo-Visium gene expression data. Daughter captures were aligned and integrated to generate a training dataset for the iSCALE model. b, Pathologist manual annotation and tissue segmentations using the predicted gene expressions from the in-sample and out-of-sample analyses for Normal 2. c, Quantitative comparison of iSCALE in-sample and out-of-sample predictions by chi-squared statistic and Spearman correlation for the top 100 HVGs, with statistics calculated across n = 1,352,947 superpixels. Gene expression predictions were binarized using the threshold 0.025. Chi-squared statistic was calculated at a spatial resolution of 8 µm, whereas Spearman correlation was evaluated across multiple spatial resolutions. For the chi-squared statistic, the red dashed lines indicate significance thresholds set at α = 0.05. For each box plot, the boundaries of the box correspond to the IQR, spanning from the 25th percentile (lower quartile) to the 75th percentile (upper quartile), with the center line indicating the median (50th percentile). Whiskers extend to the minimum and maximum values within 1.5× IQR from the lower and upper quartiles, respectively. d, Visualization of ground truth gene expression directly measured by Xenium and predicted super-resolution gene expression by iSCALE in-sample and out-of-sample predictions, shown at the 8-µm spatial resolution. The visualizations include the predicted gene expression magnitude and the corresponding binary predictions. χ2, chi-squared.

Source data

We further evaluated the accuracy of gene expression predictions for the top 100 HVGs. Because the range of gene expression is unobserved for out-of-sample predictions, evaluation metrics such as RMSE, SSIM and Pearson correlation, which rely on the magnitude of gene expression, are not suitable. Instead, we used Spearman correlation, which is rank based, and introduced a chi-squared statistic to assess overall concordance between binarized (that is, expressed or not expressed) gene expression patterns from the ground truth and predictions. As shown in Fig. 4c, 99 of the 100 genes exhibited significantly concordant out-of-sample predicted expression patterns with the ground truth. Although the correlations for out-of-sample predictions were lower than those for in-sample predictions, at the spatial resolution of 64 µm, approximately 50% of the genes achieved correlation coefficients greater than 0.45. Although predicting gene expression magnitude is challenging, out-of-sample predictions yielded correlation coefficients similar to in-sample performance. Figure 4d and Extended Data Fig. 5 present a few representative genes with varying spatial patterns, demonstrating iSCALE's strong concordance between both in-sample and out-of-sample predictions and the ground truth expression patterns.

Encouraged by the promising performance of iSCALE in benchmark evaluations, we next applied the method to data generated from a postmortem human brain of a patient with multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is a chronic inflammatory disorder that affects the central nervous system by mistakenly attacking the myelin sheath of nerve fibers, leading to inflammation and damage, which disrupts electrical impulse transmission along nerves29,30,31. Our focus is on cellular alterations in MS, specifically changes in abundance, distribution and activity of different cell types within and near MS lesions. Identifying distinct cellular profiles around MS lesions can offer insights into the disease's pathology, the immune response it provokes and potential therapeutic targets.

To characterize cell attributes associated with MS lesions, we analyzed a tissue block (Sample 1) containing an active core and complete white matter chronic active lesion from a patient with MS (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15151354)32. Because the size of the mother tissue section (approximately 22 mm × 19 mm = 418 mm2) greatly exceeded the standard ST capture area (Extended Data Fig. 6), we obtained 11 smaller daughter captures from the same tissue block following the large-tissue multi-capture study design in Fig. 1. These captures underwent gene expression analysis using the standard 10x Visium protocol with tissue capture area of 6.5 mm × 6.5 mm (Supplementary Table 1). Using the iSCALE alignment process described in the Methods section, we aligned these daughter captures onto the mother image (Fig. 5a, Extended Data Fig. 7 and Supplementary Fig. 5). Traditional ST analysis, which relies solely on observed spot-level gene expression from directly measured daughter captures, would be inadequate due to its low-resolution, spot-level segmentation and limited coverage of critical regions, such as the lesion rim and core. In contrast, iSCALE integrates gene expression information from 11 daughter captures across different regions to train a super-resolution gene expression prediction model for the entire large tissue section. For this analysis, iSCALE predicted the expression of the top 3,000 HVGs, along with 145 additional key cell type markers selected based on in-house single-nucleus RNA sequencing data generated from the same brain. As shown in Supplementary Fig. 6, the iSCALE pipeline successfully removed gene expression batch effects across all daughter captures. In total, iSCALE predicted super-resolution gene expression for the entire mother image, consisting of 2,013,871 superpixels, after downsampling for computational purposes. These super-resolution gene expression data allowed iSCALE to segment the tissue and identify regions closely matching pathologist manual annotation (Fig. 5a). iSCALE successfully detected the white matter chronic lesion core (purple cluster), the rim with increased microglial activation (red cluster), normal-appearing white matter (orange cluster) and normal-appearing gray matter (blue and green clusters) continuously across the whole mother image.

a, Mother H&E image with pathologist manual annotation, observed Visium data from 11 daughter captures obtained from adjacent tissue sections containing 36,912 spatial observations, alignment of daughter captures onto the mother image and segmentation using iSCALE's predicted gene expressions for 2,013,871 superpixels. b, Experimental validation of iSCALE's predicted gene expression using IHC stains obtained for critical markers MOG and CD68 on adjacent tissue sections. Binarized gene expression is shown for iSCALE and iStar, where a superpixel is considered expressed if its value exceeds the 25th percentile of all MOG predictions or the 25th percentile among those with expression >0.05 for CD68. Different thresholds were used because the expression range of MOG is much larger than that of CD68. Because the expression values were standardized to the range [0, 1], using a lower threshold for MOG ensures that the absolute thresholds are more comparable between MOG and CD68. c, Cell type annotation of Sample 1 using the predicted super-resolution gene expression from iSCALE across the whole mother capture. d, Cell type enrichment analysis for the identified clusters from iSCALE. Outlined in red is the enrichment for cluster confirmed by the pathologist (E.P.) as the ALR containing reactive microglia. e, Display of histological heterogeneity across distinct anatomical regions. An overlay of iSCALE segmentation on the mother H&E image (left), followed by close-up views of high-resolution H&E for four biological regions corresponding to iSCALE-identified clusters. ALR, active lesion rim; NAGM, normal-appearing gray matter; NAWM, normal-appearing white matter; WMILC, white matter inactive lesion core; E-neuron, excitatory neuron; IFNγ, interferon gamma; I-neuron, inhibitory neuron; Micro iron, iron-rich microglia; OL, oligodendrocyte; OPC, oligodendrocyte precursor cell; PVM, perivascular macrophage; Vascu, vascular.

Next, we assessed iSCALE's prediction accuracy using immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining. This technique was used to validate iSCALE's predictions for critical markers essential for identifying and classifying MS lesions, including MOG (used to discern MS lesion types based on reduced MOG immunoreactivity, indicative of demyelination) and CD68 (an activation marker of monocyte lineage). As shown in Fig. 5b, the iSCALE gene expression predictions agreed with the IHC staining patterns obtained from adjacent tissue sections. Specifically, consistent with the demyelinated nature of the MS lesion, iSCALE predicted negligible expression of MOG within the white matter chronic active lesion core. Furthermore, iSCALE's predictions indicate the presence of CD68 expression along the annotated rim of the lesion border, a pattern undetected by iStar using any of the representative daughter captures (Fig. 5b). For an in-depth analysis, we compared the observed spot-level gene expression and the predicted super-resolution gene expression for key marker genes. We illustrate this agreement for PLP1 (white matter, oligodendrocyte marker), SLC17A7 (gray matter, neuron marker) and HLA–DRA (active immune response, microglia marker), along with additional MS-related and cell type marker genes (Extended Data Fig. 8 and Supplementary Fig. 7). The predicted expression aligned closely with the spatial distribution observed in the tissues while providing substantially enhanced spatial resolution and comprehensive tissue coverage.

We further show that the super-resolution gene expression predictions by iSCALE can provide deeper insights into the cellular attributes associated with MS lesions. Using the super-resolution gene expression prediction, iSCALE automatically annotates cell types for each superpixel (Fig. 5c and Supplementary Fig. 8). We observed distinct spatial distributions of different cell types across the normal and diseased portions of the tissue, including a high density of oligodendrocytes in the normal-appearing white matter, inhibitory neurons and excitatory neurons in the gray matter, fibrous astrocytes subpopulation C (Astro fibro C) within the inactive lesion core and a mixture of iron-rich microglial and T cells in the lesion rim (Fig. 5c). By inferring cell types within these superpixels, we gained insights into the spatial distribution and diversity of cell populations within the tissue. This is particularly valuable in regions of tissue that are challenging to differentiate through histological inspection or gene expression profiling alone. For instance, the red cluster, corresponding to the active lesion rim, is enriched with immune response-related cell types, including T cells, B cells and several microglia subpopulations, such as iron-rich microglia and foamy microglia, along with infiltrated T cells within the lesion (Fig. 5d). These subpopulations are challenging for pathologists to discern from H&E images. As a comparison, we performed cell type annotation using iStar-predicted gene expressions. Unsurprisingly, the annotations were highly variable depending on which daughter capture was used for model training, and the cells were frequently annotated in locations that did not align with biological expectations. For instance, when daughter captures 612-1, 612-4 and 695-4 were used for model training, iStar predicted a high volume of inhibitory neurons in the white matter lesion core, a result that contradicts established knowledge of MS lesion biology (Extended Data Fig. 9).

To further validate the biological relevance of the iSCALE segmentation results, we compared key tissue regions: normal-appearing gray matter (clusters 1 and 2, region a), normal-appearing white matter (cluster 3, region b), active lesion rim (cluster 5, region c) and inactive lesion core (cluster 4, region d). As shown in Fig. 5e, these regions reveal distinct histological features in the H&E image. Although the inactive core exhibits fibrous structures, the active rim is denser and more heterogeneous with a mixture of immune cells. The pathologist (E.P.) confirmed that cluster 5 aligns with the hypercellular rim containing reactive microglia and that cluster 3 reflects white matter with less smoldering microglial neuroinflammation.

In this section, we explore the feasibility of using the prediction model trained on Sample 1 to predict gene expression in another MS sample. The test sample, Sample 2, was obtained from a different region of the same MS brain. Sample 2 contains a complete white matter chronic active lesion and regionally distributed active and chronic subpial cortical demyelination, as identified by manual pathologist annotation (Fig. 6a) (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15151517)33. This sample measures approximately 22.3 mm × 23.6 mm (567.7 mm2) and consists of 2,042,781 superpixels, after downsampling for computational purposes, each measuring 8 µm × 8 µm. Similar to Sample 1, gene expression in Sample 2 was originally measured using six daughter captures from the 10x Visium platform, representing only a limited area of the tissue (Supplementary Fig. 9). To demonstrate iSCALE's out-of-sample prediction capability, we applied the model trained on Sample 1's daughter captures to predict super-resolution gene expression and performed tissue segmentation in Sample 2. For comparison, we also trained iSCALE using the six daughter captures from Sample 2 for in-sample predictions. As shown in Fig. 6a, the segmentation obtained from out-of-sample predictions in Sample 2 resembles the in-sample segmentation achieved using Sample 2's own daughter captures and aligned well with the overall tissue structure annotated by the pathologist. We further validated iSCALE's out-of-sample predictions using IHC staining for MOG and CD68 obtained from adjacent tissue sections and observed that iSCALE accurately inferred the expected general locations for both markers (Fig. 6b).

a, Comparison of iSCALE segmentations for in-sample and out-of-sample predictions for Sample 2. The subpanels include the mother H&E image with pathologist manual annotation, alignment of six daughter captures onto the mother image and segmentations using iSCALE's predicted gene expressions. In-sample prediction was based on a prediction model trained using the Visium data generated from the six daughter captures for Sample 2. Out-of-sample prediction was based on a prediction model trained using the Visium data generated from the 11 daughter captures for Sample 1. b, Experimental validation of iSCALE's in-sample and out-of-sample predictions using IHC stains obtained for critical markers MOG and CD68 on adjacent tissue sections. c, Comparison of cell type annotations for in-sample and out-of-sample predictions. Displayed are the annotations for I-neurons, Astro fibro C and T cells. d, Left, segmentation based on iSCALE's in-sample predictions, overlaid with the pathologist's annotations. Right, cell type annotations derived from iSCALE's in-sample predictions. e, Cell type enrichment analysis by cluster using iSCALE's in-sample predictions.

Next, we evaluated iSCALE's performance in cell typing for out-of-sample predictions (Fig. 6c and Supplementary Fig. 10). This is more challenging than the benchmarking experiment, as the two normal samples, although from different patients, are structurally similar. In contrast, the two MS samples, although originating from the same brain, exhibit distinct lesion characteristics. Sample 1 contains an active core and complete white matter chronic active lesion, whereas Sample 2 contains a chronic active lesion and areas of active and chronic subpial cortical demyelination (Supplementary Fig. 11). Despite these marked differences between the MS samples, the out-of-sample predictions in Sample 2 successfully inferred inhibitory neurons in the gray matter cortical regions, with the locations closely matching those inferred from in-sample predictions (Fig. 6c). In addition, the out-of-sample predictions in Sample 2 mapped T cells to the expected lesion rim and astrocytes to the expected normal-appearing white matter. Although iSCALE's out-of-sample prediction is currently limited to revealing broad tissue architecture through segmentation and identifying a limited number of cell types, these promising results were achieved even across samples with distinct pathology.

Notably, iSCALE's in-sample segmentation for Sample 2 closely aligned with the pathologist's manual annotation and detected the expected cortical layer structure when the number of clusters increased (Extended Data Fig. 10). We also observed strong alignment between the identified clusters and the iSCALE cell type annotation (Fig. 6d). Notably, too, cluster 3 (green) corresponded well with oligodendrocytes and the normal-appearing white matter in the pathologist's annotation. Additionally, astrocytes (Astro fibro C), T cells and oligodendrocytes were identified throughout cluster 4 (red) corresponding to the white matter chronic active lesion (Fig. 6d,e and Supplementary Fig. 12). Furthermore, predicted biomarkers using in-sample predictions revealed tissue regions that posed challenges for manual annotation. For instance, the subpial demyelination in the cortex was annotated by the pathologist using the mother H&E image and IHC staining for MOG obtained from an adjacent tissue section (Fig. 6a,b and Supplementary Fig. 11). This introduced uncertainty in defining the borders of subpial demyelination, highlighting the challenges that pathologists face when relying on IHC staining from different adjacent slices. In contrast, iSCALE provides simultaneous predictions for all markers and enables automatic annotation on the same large tissue sample, offering a more integrated and consistent approach for tissue analysis.

In summary, we presented iSCALE, an innovative framework for rapid gene expression prediction, cell type annotation and tissue segmentation for comprehensive ST analysis of large-sized tissues, extending beyond the capabilities of conventional ST platforms. By integrating high-resolution large-scale histology images with ST data from a small set of daughter captures, iSCALE effectively processes large tissue samples. Using benchmarking data from gastric cancer and normal gastric tissues, we demonstrated iSCALE's effectiveness in semiautomatic daughter capture alignment and its ability to accurately predict super-resolution gene expression across the entire large tissue. When applied to MS brain samples, iSCALE further demonstrated its utility in assisting scientists in high-throughput and unbiased tissue annotation of entire lesions, inferring cell type compositions and pinpointing regions of interest with features not easily discernible through human visual assessment alone.

Although we demonstrated the utility of iSCALE primarily using Visium, the framework is versatile enough to be applied to other ST platforms34,35,36 and helps improve our ability to uncover meaningful functions and insights from genomic data. For example, iSCALE can employ a set of selected fields of view (FOVs) in CosMx to train the gene expression prediction model, which will enable the prediction of single-cell resolution gene expression in tissue regions outside those FOVs, thereby expanding gene expression coverage to the entire tissue section. Despite this flexibility, iSCALE does not directly account for experimental design considerations, such as the strategic and optimized selection of daughter capture regions. Future research focused on systematic approaches for region-of-interest (ROI) selection, and determining the optimal number of captures could further improve data acquisition strategies and enhance the accuracy and efficiency of downstream analyses.

Furthermore, this paper also highlights the ability of iSCALE to perform out-of-sample prediction—a highly challenging task due to the absence of observed gene expression and heterogeneity between the training and test data, especially in disease contexts. Although our results remain preliminary, given the limited training data in both the benchmarking and real-world scenarios, they carry major practical implications. H&E-stained histology images are widely accessible, cost-effective to generate and well suited for large tissue sections. We anticipate that, as more ST data are available, iSCALE will benefit from the increased training data. iSCALE's capability for out-of-sample prediction could substantially reduce experimental costs, making large-scale ST studies more feasible.

In summary, iSCALE is a computational tool that can help enhance understanding of spatial tissue architecture at the cellular level, offering valuable insights for a wide range of human diseases. This capability has the potential to make substantial contributions to future advancements in human healthcare. With the increasing adoption of ST in biomedical research, we anticipate that iSCALE will have broad applications, particularly in human studies involving large-sized tissues.

All research was conducted in accordance with relevant ethical regulations. The human gastric tissue study was approved by the institutional review board (IRB) of the Seoul Metropolitan Government–Seoul National University Boramae Medical Center (IRB no. 30-2023-1). The human MS brain tissue study was approved by the Multicentre Research Ethics Committee (08/MRE09/31+5) through the Multiple Sclerosis Society Tissue Bank at Imperial College London.

In the gastric tissue study, samples were obtained from a 63-year-old female (BS06-9313; Patient 1, Tumor and Normal 1) and a 61-year-old male (AMS-47004; Patient 2, Normal 2). The gastric cancer sample was previously profiled using the 10x Xenium platform as described in Coleman et al.15. In the present study, we generated two additional Xenium datasets from normal gastric tissues. Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded sections (5 μm) from two normal blocks were mounted on Xenium slides. Slides were deparaffinized at 60 °C for 2 hours, followed by 10 minutes in xylene jar 1 and 3 minutes sequentially in xylene jar 2, 100% ethanol jars 1 and 2, 96% ethanol jars 1 and 2 and 70% ethanol. After a 20-second water rinse, RNA decrosslinking was performed at 80 °C for 30 minutes. Probe hybridization using the 10x Human Multi-Tissue and Cancer Gene Panel V1 (377 genes) was carried out at 50 °C for 18 hours. Following protocol CG000582 (revision E), unhybridized probes were washed at 37 °C for 30 minutes, followed by 18-hour probe ligation at 37 °C and 18-hour rolling circle amplification at 30 °C. Background autofluorescence was quenched, and nuclei were fluorescently stained. Imaging was performed on the Xenium Analyzer (protocol CG000584, revision C), which conducted 15 automated cycles of probe hybridization, imaging and removal (firmware version 1.7.6.0). Image processing, including co-registration, probe filtering and nuclei/cell segmentation, was performed using xenium-1.7.1.0 software.

Postmortem human brain tissue was obtained from a 59-year-old female patient with secondary progressive MS. Two regions were sampled: one containing an active core and a chronic active lesion (Sample 1) and another containing a chronic active lesion and regionally distributed active and chronic subpial cortical demyelination (Sample 2). Fresh frozen tissue blocks were provided by Imperial College London. Blocks were equilibrated to −23 °C in a cryostat for at least 30 minutes using minimal optimal cutting temperature (OCT) compound, gently faced and sectioned to obtain full-face slices. Before and after Visium slide collection, four 10-μm-thick serial sections were mounted on Superfrost Plus Gold glass slides, fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin for 15 minutes and washed twice in PBS (10 minutes each). Slides were air dried and used for H&E, CD68 and MOG staining. CD68 and MOG staining were performed on a Leica BOND RXm or a Ventana Discovery Ultra automated stainer using standard chromogenic protocols. For antigen retrieval and permeabilization, slides were heated in EDTA buffer (pH 9) at 94 °C for 25 minutes, followed by 30-minute antibody incubation (CD68: 1:2,250, Cell Signaling Technology, D4B9C, no. 76437; MOG: 1:2,000, Abcam, EPR22629-310, no. ab233549). Bound antibodies were detected using an HRP-conjugated anti-rabbit secondary polymer and visualized with DAB and hematoxylin counterstaining. Oil Red O (ORO) staining, previously performed by Imperial College London, was used to identify lipid-laden microglia/macrophages. Whole-slide images were acquired on a Pannoramic 250 digital scanner (PerkinElmer).

MS lesion types were characterized by the relative absence of MOG immunoreactivity, indicating demyelinating regions. The reactivity of lesion types was further characterized by the activity of CD68 and ORO stain. White matter lesion types were classified into active, chronic active and chronic lesion according to Kuhlmann et al.37. In brief, white matter active lesion was characterized by the loss of MOG reactivity and the presence of large numbers of lipid-laden macrophage/microglia cells with CD68 reactivity and positive ORO stain. White matter chronic active lesion was characterized by demyelinated lesion with CD68 immunoreactivity forming a rim at the lesion border. The active rim was annotated surrounding the white matter chronic active lesion with the presence of an extensive CD68-positive cellular infiltrate, corresponding to macrophages/activated microglia as described by Absinta et al.38. Inactive lesion was annotated by demyelinated lesion with a few ramified CD68-positive cells. Cortical gray matter lesion was characterized by the loss of MOG reactivity at gray matter regions and further subtyping into subpial, leukocortical and intracortical lesions39,40. Lesions showing loss of myelin indicated by MOG staining from the outer layer into the cortex were classified as subpial lesions.

To collect tissues onto Visium Spatial Gene Expression slides (10x Genomics Slide Kit, ref. no. 1000185), a pre-chilled razor blade was used to gently score the surface of the frozen tissue block in a grid format to subdivide the tissue for placement on individual capture areas. Slides were pre-chilled prior to collection of tissue sections, and individual sections were collected onto slides by placing a fingertip on the back of the slide to promote tissue capture. Frozen slides were then processed for ST analysis according to the manufacturer's instructions (10x Visium ‘Tissue Staining & Imaging'). Sections were heated at 37 °C for 1 minute, followed by methanol fixation at −20 °C for 30 minutes. Samples were then stained with H&E. Brightfield images were collected on an Olympus VS120 Virtual Slide Microscope equipped with a VC50 camera using a UPLSAPO ×20 objective. After imaging, tissue permeabilization was carried out using the supplied permeabilization buffer at 37 °C for 6 minutes. Permeabilization time was selected based on a prior optimization experiment in mouse tissues using Visium Spatial Tissue Optimization slides (10x Genomics, ref. no. 1000193). After permeabilization, reverse transcription was carried out on-slide according to Visium guidelines.

A critical step in iSCALE is aligning daughter captures onto the mother image. Given that the daughter captures are often derived from different tissue sections and exhibit drastically different shapes, existing alignment methods fall short of adequately addressing the complexity of these data. To overcome these challenges, we developed a semiautomatic, human-in-the-loop alignment approach. This method streamlines the alignment process while maintaining the flexibility needed to handle complex data structures. The approach involves the following steps:

Step 1: Clustering spatial gene expression data in daughter captures. Apply spatial clustering algorithms—for example, BayesSpace41—to cluster gene expression data in daughter captures. We recommend generating 2–4 clusters to minimize noisy clustering patterns. The resulting clusters can then be used to facilitate the identification of key points in Step 2.

Step 2: Identify key point pairs between a daughter capture and the mother image. Identify at least four key point pairs between a daughter capture and the mother image. Use the clustering results from Step 1 as a guide to locate key points by comparing the clustering patterns observed in the daughter capture with the histological patterns in the mother image.

Step 3: Find a transformation for alignment. Use the key point pairs identified in Step 2 as input for the RANSAC algorithm implemented in OpenCV to determine a transformation between the daughter capture and the mother image. This transformation enables the alignment of the daughter capture onto the mother image.

Step 4: Align a new daughter capture. Select a new daughter capture and identify key point pairs between this capture and the mother image. Leverage the clustering results of both the new daughter capture and the previously aligned daughter capture to guide the identification of key point pairs between the new daughter capture and the mother image. Apply the RANSAC algorithm, as outlined in Step 3, to find the transformation and align the new daughter capture onto the mother image.

Step 5: Repeat alignment of remaining daughter captures. Continue the above alignment process until no additional daughter captures can be aligned.

The semiautomatic procedure described above requires minimal manual work and is relatively straightforward to implement. Extended Data Fig. 2 provides an example to illustrate how this alignment algorithm works.

To construct the iSCALE training dataset, we integrate location and gene expression information from individual ST experiments. Let qs denote the number of spatial observations in daughter capture s and define the total number of observations as \(Q={\sum }_{s=1}^{S}{q}_{s}\). For each daughter capture \(s\in \{1,\ldots ,S\}\), we define the spatial coordinate matrix \({\phi }_{s}\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{{q}_{s}\times2}\), where each row corresponds to the (x, y) coordinates of a spot. To combine the spatial locations across all captures, we concatenate the aligned coordinate matrices \({\phi }_{1},\ldots ,{\phi }_{S}\) into a single matrix \(L\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{Q\times 2}\).

Next, we combine gene expression data from multiple daughter captures. Let τs be the set of all genes measured in capture s with length ws. We define \({G}_{s}\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{{q}_{s}{\times w}_{s}}\) as the gene expression matrix for daughter capture s, where each row corresponds to a spatial measurement (that is, spot or cell), and each column corresponds to a gene. Let \(\gamma =\mathop{\bigcap }\nolimits_{s=1}^{S}{\tau }_{s}\) represent the intersection of genes shared across all captures with length |γ| = φ. To ensure comparability, we subset each expression matrix to include only genes in γ defining the reduced matrices as \({G}_{s}^{* }={G}_{s}(:,\gamma )\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{{q}_{s}\times \varphi }.\) We concatenate the reduced matrices along the spatial axis to form a unified expression matrix \(G^{*} \in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{Q\times \varphi }\). This matrix serves as a large training dataset covering spatially distinct regions of the tissue section. To further integrate information across partially overlapping daughter captures, iSCALE applies a smoothing step based on dense spatial neighborhoods defined by a distance threshold d. Within each dense neighborhood, both spatial coordinates and gene expression values are averaged to propagate information across adjacent slices. This results in a smoothed expression matrix \(\widetilde{{{G}}}\) and location matrix \(\widetilde{L}\). This integration ensures consistency across slices by effectively smoothing spatially overlapping regions.

After constructing the gene expression training dataset, iSCALE automatically selects the top HVGs across all spatial locations. The user specifies the desired number of HVGs to be selected and can optionally modify this list to include additional genes of biological or clinical interest. Let \(\mho\) denote the final set of genes used to train the iSCALE model, where \(\mho \subseteq \gamma\) and the total number of selected genes is K = |℧|. Accordingly, we subset the expression matrix \(\widetilde{{{G}}}\) to obtain \({\widetilde{{{G}}}}^{{\boldsymbol{* }}}=\widetilde{{{G}}}(:,\mho )\).

Integrating gene expression data from multiple ST captures can introduce batch effects, potentially obscuring biological signals. As shown in Supplementary Fig. 6a, this issue was evident in MS Sample 1, where daughter captures formed distinct clusters in the uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) space. To address this, iSCALE applies a minimum–maximum normalization across all daughter captures, scaling each gene to the [0, 1] range. Let \({\mathcal{G}}\) denote the normalized gene expression matrix, where each gene ‘k' is scaled as:

using the minimum and maximum expression across all spatial locations. As shown in Supplementary Fig. 6b, this procedure effectively mitigates batch effects, resulting in mixed expression profiles from different captures. iSCALE also generates pre-normalization and post-normalization UMAP plots to visualize batch effects and assess correction. If residual effects remain, users may consider alternative methods such as z-score normalization or batch correction tools such as CarDEC42 or Scanorama43 prior to model training.

Although histology images were leveraged to analyze ST data in previous works12,18,44,45, their use of histology information does not fully leverage the rich cellular information provided by high-resolution histology images. In practice, a pathologist examines histology images hierarchically—first identifying ROI by assessing high-level image features that capture global tissue structure and then examining low-level features reflecting local cellular structures.

To standardize resolution, each histology image is first rescaled so that the size of each pixel is 0.5 × 0.5 μm, making a 16 × 16-pixel tile correspond to an 8 × 8-μm2 area—approximately the size of a single cell. Next, mimicking this hierarchical review process computationally, we implement a multiscale image feature extraction strategy that captures both global and local tissue structures. This histology image feature extraction approach employs the Vision Transformer (ViT)46 in a hierarchical manner and extracts essential tissue details by breaking down the tissue image processing into stages. It starts by analyzing smaller tissue sections for the fine details, subsequently scaling up to grasp broader tissue patterns. Details of this image feature extraction were described in iStar16.

Previously, the method iStar16 was developed to enhance spatial resolution using a single ST sample as both input and training data. In our setting, however, there are multiple ST samples obtained from adjacent tissue slices, and the large target mother image lacks direct gene expression measurements. To address this, we incorporate multiple training ST samples and perform out-of-sample super-resolution gene expression prediction for the missing tissue regions. Histology features from the large-scale mother image are extracted as \(H={\left[{h}_{{mn}}\right]}_{m=1,n=1}^{M^{\prime} ,N^{\prime} }\), and gene expression prediction is performed by training on the integrated daughter data, \({\mathcal{G}}\), to minimize the specified objective function.

Specifically, when the daughter capture is from a sequencing-based ST platform, such as 10x Visium, then iSCALE integrates histology features and ST data using a spot-level weakly supervised loss function, allowing differences in spatial resolution between training and prediction. The loss, \({{\mathcal{L}}}_{\rm{{Seq}}}\), is computed over all observed spots \(q\in Q\) where \({g}_{k}\) is the prediction model for gene k; \({{\mathcal{M}}}_{q}\) is the spot mask of q (the collection of superpixels covered by spot q); and hmn is the histology feature at superpixel (m, n):

When the daughter captures are from an imaging-based ST platform, such as 10x Xenium or CosMx, iSCALE employs a directly supervised loss function using gene expression labels available at the superpixel level during training:

where P denotes the set of superpixels across all daughter captures. After model training, gene expression at each superpixel (m, n) in the mother image is predicted as \({\hat{y}}_{{kmn}}={g}_{k}({h}_{{mn}})\), yielding the continuous super-resolution gene expression image \({\hat{Y}}_{k}=[\;{\hat{y}}_{{kmn}}]_{m=1,n=1}^{{M}^{{\prime} },{N}^{{\prime} }}\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{{M}^{{\prime} }{N}^{{\prime} }}\) across the entire large-scale mother image for each gene k.

A multilayer perceptron architecture was used, consisting of a feedforward neural network with four hidden layers, each containing 256 neurons and employing a leaky rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation function (α = 0.1). The model was trained with a batch size of 100 using the Adam optimizer (learning rate 1 × 10−3) for 1,000 epochs across three random initialization states. The loss function minimized the difference between predicted and observed gene expression, at either the spot level (iSCALE-Seq) or the superpixel level (iSCALE-Img), depending on the resolution of the training data. No formal hyperparameter optimization was conducted; instead, architecture and training parameters were chosen based on prior experience and performance evaluation using RMSE loss. Training and validation were conducted on an NVIDIA graphics processing unit (GPU) with 64 GB of memory to accommodate the largest tissue sample.

We ran iSCALE on a server equipped with an NVIDIA GPU (driver version 550.54.15, CUDA 12.4). For the MS data, we used a single GPU with 64 GB of memory for Sample 1 and 32 GB of memory for Sample 2. The process of extracting histology image features, smoothing and exporting data took approximately 13 minutes for Sample 1 and 15 minutes for Sample 2. Integrating data across daughter captures, training the gene expression prediction model (1,000 epochs, repeated for three random states), predicting gene expression and exporting super-resolution gene expression data for 1,000 genes required 1 hour and 35 minutes for Sample 1 and 54 minutes for Sample 2.

The predicted gene expression can be used for tissue segmentation through clustering analysis with the k-means algorithm. iSCALE provides two options for this clustering analysis. The first option uses the embedding from the last hidden layer in the gene expression prediction neural network model as input, and the second option uses principal components derived from the predicted gene expression as input. By the end of the clustering analysis, iSCALE partitions the tissue into functionally distinct regions in an unsupervised manner based on their gene expression profiles.

To support interpretation of segmented tissue regions and reveal cell population heterogeneity, iSCALE performs cell type inference at the superpixel level across the full tissue section. Each superpixel is treated as an artificial cell, with its cell type label inferred using iSCALE-predicted gene expression and a marker gene reference panel. The traditional score-based approach from iStar16 often yields overdominant predictions, assigning a single cell type broadly—especially when marker genes have outlier or inflated expression, which is more likely when training data come from multiple ST captures. To address this, iSCALE introduces key modifications for more robust cell type annotation.

Let V be the total number of candidate cell types in the marker reference set. For each cell type \(v\in \{1,\ldots ,V\;\}\), suppose that we have a list of marker gene names ψv. In iSCALE, we apply a filtering criterion based on prediction uncertainty for genes in the marker set. Specifically, we compute the training RMSE for each gene and remove those exceeding the 95th percentile across all genes, yielding a refined marker set \({\psi }_{v}^{* }\). This step eliminates genes that are poorly predicted in the training set from being selected as a candidate for cell typing. For each gene in \({\psi }_{v}^{* }\), we then compute its percentile expression across all superpixels in the tissue. For each marker gene, the predicted super-resolution gene expression is transformed to \({\widetilde{Y}}_{k}^{* }=[\;{\widetilde{y}}_{{kmn}}^{* }]_{m=1,n=1}^{{M}^{{\prime} },{N}^{{\prime} }}\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{{M}^{{\prime} }{N}^{{\prime} }}\), where we define \({\widetilde{y}}_{{kmn}}^{* }={\sum }_{{\rm{i}}=1}^{{M}^{{\prime} }{N}^{{\prime} }}1({\hat{Y}}_{k}\le {\hat{y}}_{{kmn}})/{(M}^{{\prime} }{N}^{{\prime} })\) with \({1(\hat{Y}}_{k}\le {\hat{y}}_{{kmn}})\), representing an indicator function that equals 1 if \({\hat{Y}}_{k}\le {\hat{y}}_{{kmn}}\) and 0 otherwise. This transformation standardizes the data into the range of [0, 1] while removing the large impact of outlying or overpredicted expression on the marker score calculation. For each superpixel (m, n), we compute the score, uvmn, for each cell type v by averaging the percentile transformed gene expression across its marker genes: \({u}_{{vmn}}=|{{\psi }_{v}^{* }|}^{-1}\sum _{k\in {\psi }_{v}^{* }}{\widetilde{y}}_{{kmn}}^{* }\), where \(\left|{\psi }_{v}^{* }\right|\) is the number of genes in \({\psi }_{v}^{* }\). To infer the cell type of superpixel (m, n), let \({t}_{{mn}}^{\max}=\mathop{{\rm{arg}}}\limits_{1\le {\rm{v}}\le {\rm{V}}}\max {u}_{{tmn}}\) be the cell type with the maximal score and \({u}_{{mn}}^{\max }=\mathop{\max }\limits_{1\le {\rm{v}}\le {\rm{V}}}{u}_{{tmn}}\) be the score of this cell type. Given a predetermined threshold \({u}_{{{\rm{threshold}}}}\in \left[0.0,1.0\right]\), if \({{u}_{{mn}}^{\max } > u}_{{{\rm{threshold}}}}\), then the cell type of superpixel (m, n) is predicted to be \({v}_{{mn}}^{\max }\); otherwise, the cell type of this superpixel is unclassified. In our experiments, we set \({u}_{{{\rm{threshold}}}}=0.05\) and found it effective in most cases.

Overall, the adjusted score-based approach sets thresholds more consistently across datasets with varying magnitudes of imputed expression and reduces reliance on arbitrary cutoffs typical of standard methods. The percentile adjustment mitigates the influence of outlier genes with high predicted expression that might otherwise skew scores and lead to a dominant cell type label, improving robustness to marker gene selection. Although our pipeline uses this percentile-based scoring, iSCALE also allows users to apply any preferred cell type annotation method to the predicted super-resolution gene expression. After cell type inference, iSCALE performs enrichment analysis by identifying abundant cell types within each tissue cluster to reveal biological activity for different spatial regions.

For in-sample predictions, we evaluated model performance using three metrics per gene. First, RMSE was calculated as \(1/\sqrt{n}\) times the Euclidean distance between observed and predicted expression across n superpixels. Expression values were normalized to [0, 1], allowing RMSE to quantify the accuracy of vectorized predictions. Second, we used the SSIM, which assesses both intensity and spatial structural similarity between expression images; SSIM scores range from 0 to 1, with 1 indicating perfect similarity. Third, Pearson correlation was used to assess the linear relationship between observed and predicted values.

For out-of-sample predictions, where absolute gene expression magnitudes in the test data are unobserved, we instead applied Spearman correlation, which compares the ranks of expression values. We also evaluated concordance between binarized ground truth and predicted expression using a chi-squared test, categorizing gene expression as ‘expressed' or ‘not expressed' based on a predefined threshold. This test follows a chi-squared distribution with 1 degree of freedom under the null hypothesis of no association. Resulting P values were corrected for multiple testing across genes using the Bonferroni method. To account for extremely high values, the \({-\log }_{10}P\) metric was capped at a maximum of 10; values exceeding this threshold were set to 10.

Further information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article.

We analyzed the following datasets in this study: (1) 10x Xenium spatial transcriptomics data from a human patient with gastric cancer, tumor sample (Gastric Patient 1, Tumor) (IRB no. 30-2023-1 (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15164980)). Five pseudo-Visium captures derived from the whole-slide sample were generated for benchmarking. (2) 10x Xenium spatial transcriptomics data from a human patient with gastric cancer, normal sample (Gastric Patient 1, Normal 1) (IRB no. 30-2023-1 (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15164978)). Eleven pseudo-Visium captures derived from the whole-slide sample were generated for benchmarking. (3) 10x Xenium spatial transcriptomics data from a healthy human gastric patient, normal sample (Gastric Patient 2, Normal 2) (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15164947). Eight pseudo-Visium captures derived from the whole-slide sample were generated for benchmarking. (4) Human large-sized MS brain sample, MS330-AL (MS Brain Sample 1). Eleven 10x Visium spatial transcriptomics samples corresponding to partial tissue regions from adjacent slices and high-resolution H&E image of the full large tissue section (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15151354). (5) Human large-sized MS brain sample, MS330-CAL (MS Brain Sample 2). Six 10x Visium ST samples corresponding to partial tissue regions from adjacent slices and high-resolution H&E image of the full large tissue section (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15151517). The benchmarking data generated from the gastric tumor sample are available as a demo for our method on GitHub (https://github.com/amesch441/iSCALE). All benchmarking datasets generated can be publicly accessed at https://upenn.box.com/s/cburekr425ibu276wyxki09q35z2o3x0. Details of the real-world large-tissue MS datasets analyzed in this study are provided in Supplementary Table 1. All datasets referenced in this paper have been made publicly available via Zenodo. Source data are provided with this paper.

The iSCALE algorithm was implemented in Python and is available on GitHub at https://github.com/amesch441/iSCALE.

a, Ideal grid-based layout design: The tissue is divided into a grid, and each section (daughter capture) is profiled using an ST platform (for example 10x Visium). This layout allows for systematic and contiguous spatial coverage of the tissue. b, Real-world adjacent tissue slice design: Daughter captures are obtained from adjacent sections of the same tissue block. Due to technical and experimental challenges of tissue processing, these captures often only partially overlap in the X-Y plane, and gaps may arise, leaving regions of the mother tissue unmeasured.

a, Key point detection step showing spatial coordinates from a pseudo-Visium daughter capture (left) and corresponding landmarks in the H&E-stained mother image (right). b, Example alignment of a daughter capture (D6) to the mother image using detected key points. c, Final alignment results for ten daughter captures overlaid on the mother image using the alignment pipeline described in the Methods section. d, iSCALE alignment accuracy across ten daughter captures. For each daughter capture, the percentage of overlapping pixels between the aligned and true capture location is reported. The blue box indicates the true location of each daughter capture, and the black box indicates the iSCALE aligned location of the daughter capture.

a-d, Quantitative comparison of iSCALE and iStar predictions using RMSE, SSIM, and Pearson correlation. Statistics were calculated across n = 1,971,625 superpixels. RMSE and SSIM were evaluated at 8 µm spatial resolution, while Pearson correlation was assessed at multiple spatial resolutions. iSCALE-Seq: iSCALE trained using pseudo-Visium daughter captures. iSCALE-Img: iSCALE trained using Xenium daughter captures. a,b, Comparisons for top 100 SVGs, identified by Moran's I, evaluated separately for each iStar model (D1-D5), resulting in 500 gene-wise comparisons. c,d, Comparisons for all genes captured in the Xenium data (377 genes), evaluated separately for each iStar model (D1-D5), resulting in 1885 gene-wise comparisons. a,c, For each boxplot, the boundaries of the box correspond to the interquartile range (IQR), spanning from the 25th percentile (lower quartile) to the 75th percentile (upper quartile), with the center line indicating the median (50th percentile). Whiskers extend to the minimum and maximum values within 1.5 x IQR from the lower and upper quartiles, respectively. Data beyond the end of the whiskers are plotted individually. b,d, Direct comparison of iSCALE-Seq versus iStar predictions at the per-gene level; the blue diagonal line indicates parity between methods.

Title: Weird ‘time crystals' are made visible at last
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Search author on:
PubMed
 Google Scholar


A time crystal as seen under a microscope.Credit: Zhao & Smalyukh, 2025, Nature Materials

A time crystal is a form of matter that shows continuous, repeating patterns over time, much like how atoms in a normal crystal repeat in space. Examples once existed in only complex, quantum matter, but now physicists have found a way to make a time crystal that can be seen, under certain conditions, with the naked eye.

The feat, accomplished by physicists at the University of Colorado Boulder, and published in Nature Materials on 4 September1, involved liquid crystals — bar-shaped molecules with properties between those of a liquid and those of a solid. Simply by shining a light on the liquid crystals, the team created ripples of twisting molecules through them. The ripples kept moving for hours, undulating with a distinct beat, even when the researchers changed the conditions. The rhythm was also out of sync with any incoming force — fulfilling the two defining criteria for a time crystal.

Although some of this behaviour of liquid crystals was already known, no one had previously considered whether it could be harnessed to make a time crystal, says Young-Ki Kim, a material scientist at the Pohang University of Science and Technology in South Korea.

The macroscopic scale of the time crystal — at millimetres to centimetres across — creates opportunities “to provide deeper understanding” of the phenomena, he says. The distinctive patterns in the crystals could also allow them to be used in anti-counterfeit devices, say the authors.



Nobel prizewinning physicist Frank Wilczek first proposed the idea of a time crystal in 2012. Wilczek's version was almost like a perpetual-motion machine; something that cycled endlessly while in its natural resting state. A team later published a paper that mathematically proved this concept was impossible2, but researchers soon found that other kinds of time crystal were possible. Ordered time crystals could exist, for example, in bizarre systems that were perpetually in flux, rather than at rest.

Time crystals have since been made in a variety of ways, using interacting nanoscale defects in diamonds, trapped ions and simulated on Google's Sycamore quantum computer. But most examples have been at the microscopic scale.

The latest system involves shining a light, even that from a normal light bulb, on a liquid-crystal film trapped between two glass plates. When the light hits photosensitive dye molecules on the glass plates, they switch their orientation, which triggers molecules in the liquid crystal to begin twisting.

Intermolecular forces between rod-like liquid crystal molecules mean that they usually all point in the same direction. If some begin twisting, this sets off a domino effect: the molecules reorient themselves in a complex interaction that moves across the sample like a Mexican wave. 

From this soup of molecules arise stable twisted formations that behave like particles. These particles interact with each other to create observable ripples. “We were surprised and excited to see that such time crystalline order can be readily observed in soft matter systems,” says Ivan Smalyukh, a physicist at the University of Colorado Boulder, who led the work.

To observe the molecular dance in detail, the authors looked at the time-crystal system using a kind of microscope that transmits only polarized light. The amount of light that passes through depends on a molecule's alignment, revealing the time crystal's ripples as a series of dark and bright stripes.

Title: Heroes or hoarders? The strange brains of people who collect
Description:

Andrew Robinson is a writer based in London and author of Einstein in Oxford (2024) and other books.


Search author on:
PubMed
 Google Scholar


Parts of Hans Sloane's extensive collection are held in the British Museum and the Natural History Museum in London. Credit: Alamy

A Noble Madness: The Dark Side of Collecting from Antiquity to Now James Delbourgo Riverrun (2025)

The Galileo Museum, a science museum in Florence, Italy, has astronomer Galileo Galilei's preserved middle finger on display. Encased in a gilded glass egg, the digit is exhibited “as if it were the relic of a Christian saint”, remarks historian of science James Delbourgo in his illuminating and entertaining history of the ‘dark side' of humanity's obsession with collecting things. The finger was severed from Galileo's corpse in 1737 — long after his death in 1642 — along with an index finger also displayed at the museum and a vertebra held at the University of Padua, Italy. According to a witness to the dismemberment, the Italian nobleman who took the fingers desired them “because Galileo wrote so many beautiful things with them”.

How a self-taught biologist transformed nature writing — and inspired Darwin

How a self-taught biologist transformed nature writing — and inspired Darwin

It is an unusual story, but perhaps not entirely atypical. As Delbourgo shows in A Noble Madness, a large driver of the desire to collect artefacts is curiosity — whether scientific, historical, religious or otherwise. But perhaps even more often, it is obsession. Delbourgo focuses on this compulsive aspect, and the varying ways in which society has regarded people who are driven to amass stuff. He offers “a grand portrait gallery that charts the changing image of the collector from the ancient looter and medieval idolater to the decadent of the fin de siècle and the modern-day hoarder”.

A compelling example of such obsession is Henry Wellcome. He is known today through the biomedical research-funding organization Wellcome, and the Wellcome Collection museum and library in London. Born in 1853 to an itinerant missionary father in a log cabin in Wisconsin, by his death in 1936, Wellcome had become a highly successful pharmaceutical entrepreneur in the United Kingdom. He also owned a grotesquely overwhelming collection of objects, the variety and sheer number of which the world had never seen — mainly because few were on display.

‘Natural history museums can save the world': anti-colonialism, conservation and climate change

‘Natural history museums can save the world': anti-colonialism, conservation and climate change

Wellcome obtained many of these objects through highly dubious means, notes Frances Larson in her disturbing 2009 history of his collection, An Infinity of Things. In 1912, for example, Wellcome's right-hand man wrote to an agent in India, a doctor, that the country must be “completely ransacked as far as we possibly can for literature and other objects of interest connected with ancient medicine”. The agent duly did his best — but there is little evidence that Wellcome ever studied or ‘enjoyed' what had been collected. He was always too busy acquiring new things, right up to his death. His obsession was rooted in possession.

The Wellcome Museum deliberately avoids displaying information about its founder, notes Delbourgo. He regards this stance as “myopic: the Wellcome's abdication of its duty to educate visitors about its origins denies the public the chance to make up its own mind about its past”.

The British Museum, just down the road in London, is less coy about the man who provided its founding collection in 1753. Physician and naturalist Hans Sloane — the subject of Delbourgo's 2017 book Collecting the World — was an avid collector of curiosities and animal and plant specimens. His motivations were multifarious. He collected manuscripts from astrologers and alchemists to document their ascientific convictions as “disorders of the mind”, delusions that he felt might be cured by bloodletting, his specialism. But when it came to collecting from the natural world, he was explicit about a financial incentive: to “figure out what species were good for, what they cost, and how to make money off them”, in Delbourgo's words. To his critics, Sloane was an “ignorant arriviste”. Today, his financial links to the slave plantations in Jamaica that part-funded his collecting are openly acknowledged in an exhibit showing a bust of Sloane.

Galileo's elegantly preserved middle finger.Credit: Eric Vandeville/Gamma-Rapho/Getty

Title: USA Today Enters Its Gen AI Era With a Chatbot
Description:
The publishing company behind USA Today and 220 other publications is today rolling out a chatbot-like tool called DeeperDive that can converse with readers, summarize insights from its journalism, and suggest new content from across its sites.

“Visitors now have a trusted AI answer engine on our platform for anything they want to engage with, anything they want to ask,” said Mike Reed, CEO of Gannett and the USA Today Network, at the WIRED AI Power Summit in New York, an event that brought together voices from the tech industry, politics, and the world of media, “and it is performing really great.”

Most publishers have a fraught relationship with AI, as the chatbots that trained on their content are now summarizing it and eating the traffic that search engines used to send them.

Reed said that Google's AI Overview feature has dramatically cut traffic to publishers across the industry. “We are watching the same movie as everyone else is watching,” Reed said ahead of today's announcement. “We can see some risk in the future to any content distribution model that is based primarily on SEO optimization.”

Like other publishers, Gannett has signed some deals with AI companies, including Amazon and Perplexity, to license its content. The company actively blocks the web scrapers that crawl websites in order to steal content.

DeeperDive represents a bet that harnessing the same generative artificial intelligence technology could help publishers capture readers attention by engaging with them in new ways.

The tool replaces a conventional search box and automatically suggests questions that readers might want to ask. For example, today it offers as one prompt, “How does Trump's Fed policy affect the economy?”

DeeperDive generates a short answer to the query along with relevant stories from across the USA Today network. Reed says it is crucial that DeeperDive bases its output on factually correct information and does not draw from opinion pieces. “We only look at our real journalism,” he says.

The interface of DeeperDive on the homepage of USA Today

Reed adds that his company hopes that the tool will also reveal more about readers' interests. “That can help us from a revenue standpoint,” he said.

DeeperDive was developed by the advertising company Taboola. Adam Singolda, Taboola's CEO, says his firm developed DeeperDive by fine-tuning several open source models.

Singolda says DeeperDive benefits from data gathered from across its own network of more than 600 million daily readers across around 11,000 publishers. He says the tool “grounds every answer in articles retrieved from our publisher partners and requires sentence-level citations to those sources” and will avoid generating an output if information from two sources seems to conflict.

Gannett's CEO Reed said ahead of today's event that, together with Taboola, his firm is interested in exploring agentic tools for readers' shopping decisions. “Our audiences have a higher intent to purchase to begin with,” he says. “That's really the next step here.”
